 I hope you realize that this must have been a joke poll, not a real one - or just a joke article. 
 
 Nevertheless, there is a general trend that most Americans don't discuss class issues since they have an unrealistic expectation that their probability of getting rich is sufficiently high or that those who are rich earned all of their wealth (as opposed to often taking a very disproportionate share of the wealth that was earned by group effort). American CEOs as a group are far better paid on average than those of other Westernized countries. Most Americans either don't see that or don't care because of the mythologized American dream. The American Dream certainly does still exist but inter-class mobility is not nearly as high as many imagine.

Geesh! CUNx, you don't sound like much of a "fat cat" to me. Why are you getting so incensed about someone else's taxes going up?
 
 You sure didn't raise a ruckus when us poor working slobs started paying more taxes on our income than those poor little ol' "fat cats."
 
Warren Buffett, the third-richest man in the world, has criticised the US tax system for allowing him to pay a lower rate than his secretary and his cleaner.
 
 Speaking at a $4,600-a-seat fundraiser in New York for Senator Hillary Clinton, Mr Buffett, who is worth an estimated $52 billion (£26 billion), said: "The 400 of us [here] pay a lower part of our income in taxes than our receptionists do, or our cleaning ladies, for that matter. If you're in the luckiest 1 per cent of humanity, you owe it to the rest of humanity to think about the other 99 per cent."
 
 Mr Buffett said that he was taxed at 17.7 per cent on the $46 million he made last year, without trying to avoid paying higher taxes, while his secretary, who earned $60,000, was taxed at 30 per cent. Mr Buffett told his audience, which included John Mack, the chairman of Morgan Stanley, and Alan Patricof, the founder of the US branch of Apax Partners, that US government policy had accentuated a disparity of wealth that hurt the economy by stifling opportunity and motivation.
 
 Buffett blasts system that lets him pay less tax than secretary
